monitoring_type: GI bleeding signs, Renal function, Cardiovascular risk
major_contraindications: Active peptic ulcer,Severe heart failure,Coronary artery bypass surgery (perioperative period),Third trimester pregnancy,Aspirin triad (asthma nasal polyps aspirin sensitivity)
black_box_warning_text: Increased risk of serious cardiovascular thrombotic events MI and stroke. Increased risk of serious GI bleeding ulceration and perforation. Contraindicated for perioperative pain in CABG surgery.
major_drug_interactions: Warfarin (increased bleeding),Aspirin (increased GI bleeding),ACE inhibitors (reduced antihypertensive effect),Diuretics (reduced effect),Lithium (increased levels),Methotrexate (increased toxicity)
food_interactions: Take with food to reduce GI upset
notes: Potent NSAID. High cardiovascular and GI risk. Available oral and topical. Topical safer for localized pain.

major_contraindications: Active peptic ulcer,Severe heart failure,CABG perioperative period,Third trimester pregnancy,Aspirin sensitivity
black_box_warning_text: Increased CV thrombotic events and GI bleeding risk.
major_drug_interactions: Warfarin (bleeding),Aspirin (GI bleeding),ACE inhibitors (reduced effect),SSRIs (GI bleeding),Methotrexate (toxicity)
food_interactions: Take with food
notes: Long-acting NSAID. Twice-daily dosing. Lower CV risk than some other NSAIDs.

monitoring_type: GI symptoms, CNS effects (headache confusion), Renal function
major_contraindications: Active peptic ulcer,Severe heart failure,CABG perioperative,Premature infants with PDA (different indication),Rectal bleeding
black_box_warning_text: High risk of serious CV and GI adverse events. CNS side effects common (headache dizziness confusion).
major_drug_interactions: Warfarin (bleeding),Aspirin (GI bleeding),Lithium (increased lithium toxicity),Triamterene (acute renal failure risk),Methotrexate (toxicity)
food_interactions: Take with food or milk
notes: Very potent NSAID. High side effect profile. Reserved for specific conditions like acute gout. CNS effects common.

major_contraindications: Active peptic ulcer,Severe heart failure,CABG perioperative,Third trimester pregnancy
black_box_warning_text: Higher GI bleeding risk than other NSAIDs. Increased CV thrombotic risk.
major_drug_interactions: Warfarin (severe bleeding risk),Aspirin (GI bleeding),ACE inhibitors (reduced effect),Lithium (increased levels)
food_interactions: Take with food
notes: Long-acting NSAID. Once-daily. Higher GI bleeding risk than other NSAIDs. Use limited now.

monitoring_type: Cardiovascular events, GI symptoms, Renal function
major_contraindications: Sulfonamide allergy,Active peptic ulcer,Severe heart failure,CABG perioperative,Third trimester pregnancy
black_box_warning_text: Increased CV thrombotic risk especially with prolonged use. May increase risk of serious CV events MI and stroke.
major_drug_interactions: Warfarin (bleeding),ACE inhibitors (reduced effect),Fluconazole (increased celecoxib levels),Lithium (increased levels)
food_interactions: Take with or without food
notes: COX-2 selective NSAID. Lower GI bleeding risk than non-selective NSAIDs. CV risk still present. Sulfa allergy contraindication.

major_contraindications: Active peptic ulcer,Inflammatory bowel disease,Severe renal impairment,Third trimester pregnancy
major_drug_interactions: Warfarin (bleeding),Aspirin (GI bleeding),Magnesium-based antacids (increased mefenamic acid absorption)
food_interactions: Take with food, maximum 7 days use
notes: NSAID popular for menstrual pain (dysmenorrhea). Short-term use only (7 days max). GI side effects common.

monitoring_type: GI bleeding, Renal function, Bleeding risk
major_contraindications: Active peptic ulcer,Advanced renal impairment,High bleeding risk,CABG perioperative,Labor and delivery,Concurrent aspirin or other NSAIDs
black_box_warning_text: High risk of serious GI bleeding perforation and ulceration. Increased bleeding risk. Renal impairment and failure. Maximum 5 days use (oral and injectable combined).
major_drug_interactions: Warfarin (severe bleeding),Aspirin (contraindicated),ACE inhibitors (renal impairment),Pentoxifylline (bleeding),Probenecid (increased ketorolac levels - contraindicated)
food_interactions: Take with food, maximum 5 days total therapy
notes: Potent NSAID for short-term severe pain. Maximum 5 days use (oral+IV combined). High bleeding and GI risk. Black box warnings.

major_contraindications: Active peptic ulcer,Severe heart failure,CABG perioperative,Third trimester pregnancy
major_drug_interactions: Warfarin (bleeding),Aspirin (GI bleeding),ACE inhibitors (reduced effect),Cholestyramine (reduced meloxicam absorption)
food_interactions: Take with or without food
notes: Preferential COX-2 inhibitor. Once-daily dosing. Lower GI risk than non-selective NSAIDs. Still has CV and GI risks.

monitoring_type: Blood pressure, Cardiovascular events, GI symptoms
major_contraindications: Active peptic ulcer,Inflammatory bowel disease,Uncontrolled hypertension,Established ischemic heart disease,Peripheral arterial disease,Cerebrovascular disease,Heart failure
black_box_warning_text: Increased CV thrombotic risk. Not approved in US due to CV concerns.
major_drug_interactions: Warfarin (bleeding),ACE inhibitors (reduced effect),Rifampicin (reduced etoricoxib levels),Oral contraceptives (increased hormone levels)
food_interactions: Take with or without food
notes: COX-2 selective. Once-daily. Not approved in US (CV concerns). Popular elsewhere. Dose-dependent CV risk. Monitor BP.

monitoring_type: Pain level, Respiratory function, Constipation, Addiction signs
major_contraindications: Respiratory depression,Acute asthma,Paralytic ileus,Children under 12 (codeine metabolism issues)
black_box_warning_text: Risk of respiratory depression addiction and abuse. Codeine metabolism to morphine varies (ultra-rapid metabolizers at risk). Constipation common.
major_drug_interactions: CNS depressants (respiratory depression),MAOIs (severe reactions),Warfarin (paracetamol increases INR)
food_interactions: Take with food, monitor for constipation
notes: Opioid combination. Addiction and respiratory depression risk. Codeine variable metabolism. Avoid in children <12.

monitoring_type: Pain level, Seizure risk, Serotonin syndrome, Addiction
major_contraindications: Respiratory depression,Acute intoxication with alcohol/drugs,MAOIs,Epilepsy (uncontrolled),Children under 12
black_box_warning_text: Seizure risk at high doses. Serotonin syndrome risk with SSRIs/SNRIs. Addiction and respiratory depression risk.
major_drug_interactions: MAOIs (serotonin syndrome - contraindicated),SSRIs (serotonin syndrome),CNS depressants (respiratory depression),Warfarin (increased INR from paracetamol)
food_interactions: Take with or without food, avoid alcohol
notes: Combination for moderate pain. Tramadol NAFDAC-controlled since 2018. Seizure and serotonin syndrome risk.

monitoring_type: Pain, Respiratory function, Liver function, Addiction
major_contraindications: Respiratory depression,Severe asthma,Paralytic ileus,Hypersensitivity
black_box_warning_text: High abuse and addiction potential. Respiratory depression risk. Hepatotoxicity from paracetamol (acetaminophen) especially with alcohol use. Reclassified Schedule II in US (2014).
major_drug_interactions: CNS depressants (fatal respiratory depression),Alcohol (liver damage + respiratory depression),MAOIs (severe reactions),Benzodiazepines (respiratory depression),CYP3A4 inhibitors (increased hydrocodone levels)
food_interactions: Take with food, avoid alcohol completely, monitor liver function
search_keywords: vicodin|norco|hydrocodone paracetamol|opioid combination|moderate to severe pain
notes: Potent opioid combination. High abuse potential. Monitor liver function due to paracetamol. Limit paracetamol total daily dose.

major_contraindications: Active peptic ulcer,Hemophilia,Children under 12 with viral illness (Reye's syndrome),Third trimester pregnancy,Severe renal/hepatic impairment
major_drug_interactions: Warfarin (bleeding),Other NSAIDs (increased GI bleeding),Methotrexate (increased toxicity),ACE inhibitors (reduced effect),Corticosteroids (increased GI bleeding)
food_interactions: Take with food or after meals with full glass of water
notes: Analgesic/antipyretic dose (300-600mg). GI bleeding risk. Avoid in children <12 (Reye's syndrome). Take with food.

major_contraindications: Active peptic ulcer,Severe renal/hepatic impairment,Third trimester pregnancy,NSAID hypersensitivity
major_drug_interactions: Warfarin (bleeding from both components),ACE inhibitors (reduced effect from ibuprofen),Lithium (increased levels)
food_interactions: Take with food, maximum 3 days without medical advice
notes: Fixed-dose combination. Better pain relief than either alone. Short-term use only. GI precautions from ibuprofen.

mechanism_of_action: Blocks sodium channels (prevents nerve impulse transmission)
major_contraindications: Hypersensitivity to ester anesthetics,Infants under 2 years (methemoglobinemia risk)
black_box_warning_text: Risk of methemoglobinemia especially in children under 2 years. Can be fatal. FDA warnings against use in teething infants.
major_drug_interactions: None significant
food_interactions: Topical use only, apply sparingly to affected area
notes: Topical anesthetic for oral pain. Black box warning for methemoglobinemia in infants. Avoid in children <2.

major_contraindications: Hypersensitivity to amide anesthetics,Application to large areas or broken skin
major_drug_interactions: Class I antiarrhythmics (additive cardiac effects if absorbed systemically)
food_interactions: Topical use only, do not apply to large areas
notes: Topical local anesthetic. Safer than benzocaine in children. Available as patches gels and ointments. For localized pain.

mechanism_of_action: Depletes substance P from sensory neurons
major_contraindications: Hypersensitivity,Broken or irritated skin
major_drug_interactions: None significant
food_interactions: Topical use only, wash hands after application, avoid eyes and mucous membranes, initial burning common
notes: Topical analgesic from chili peppers. Depletes substance P. Initial burning/stinging for first week. Good for neuropathic pain and arthritis.

major_contraindications: Aspirin allergy,Children under 12,Broken skin,Concurrent warfarin use
major_drug_interactions: Warfarin (systemic absorption can increase INR),Other salicylates (additive effects)
food_interactions: Topical use only, do not apply heat, do not bandage tightly, avoid broken skin
search_keywords: methyl salicylate|deep heat|ralgex|muscle pain|topical pain relief
notes: Topical counterirritant for muscle pain. Absorption can occur (avoid in aspirin allergy). Popular in Nigeria for muscle aches.

major_contraindications: Hypersensitivity,Infants under 2 years (respiratory issues if applied to face/nose)
major_drug_interactions: None significant
food_interactions: Topical use only, avoid broken skin, do not apply to face of infants
notes: Topical counterirritant with cooling effect. Safe and well-tolerated. Avoid in infants <2 on face/nose area.

major_contraindications: Aspirin triad (asthma nasal polyps aspirin allergy),Third trimester pregnancy,Open wounds or eczema at application site
black_box_warning_text: Lower systemic exposure than oral NSAIDs but still has CV and GI risks with prolonged use. Avoid in late pregnancy.
major_drug_interactions: Oral NSAIDs (additive effects - avoid concurrent use),Warfarin (may increase bleeding risk)
food_interactions: Topical use only, apply thin layer and rub in gently, wash hands after use (unless treating hands)
notes: Topical NSAID. Much lower systemic exposure than oral. Good for localized joint pain. Still has some systemic absorption.

mechanism_of_action: Binds to alpha-2-delta subunit of voltage-gated calcium channels
monitoring_type: Pain level, Dizziness, Peripheral edema, Suicidal ideation
major_contraindications: Hypersensitivity to pregabalin
major_drug_interactions: Opioids (increased respiratory depression risk),CNS depressants (enhanced sedation),Alcohol (enhanced sedation)
food_interactions: Take with or without food, avoid abrupt discontinuation
notes: For neuropathic pain and fibromyalgia. Abuse potential (controlled in many countries). Dizziness and sedation common. Weight gain and edema.

mechanism_of_action: Binds to alpha-2-delta subunit of voltage-gated calcium channels
major_contraindications: Hypersensitivity to gabapentin
major_drug_interactions: Opioids (increased respiratory depression),Antacids (reduced gabapentin absorption),Morphine (increased gabapentin levels)
food_interactions: Take with or without food, space from antacids by 2 hours, avoid abrupt discontinuation
notes: For neuropathic pain and seizures. Less abuse potential than pregabalin. Dizziness common. Requires renal dose adjustment. Three times daily dosing.

major_contraindications: MAOIs within 14 days,Uncontrolled narrow-angle glaucoma,Severe hepatic impairment,Severe renal impairment
black_box_warning_text: Increased risk of suicidal thoughts and behavior in children adolescents and young adults with depression. Not approved for use in children.
major_drug_interactions: MAOIs (serotonin syndrome - contraindicated),SSRIs (serotonin syndrome),Tramadol (serotonin syndrome),Warfarin (increased bleeding risk),CYP1A2 inhibitors (increased duloxetine levels)
food_interactions: Take with or without food, avoid abrupt discontinuation (taper)
notes: SNRI for neuropathic pain depression and fibromyalgia. Black box for suicidality. Nausea common initially. Avoid abrupt discontinuation.

monitoring_type: Pain level, Anticholinergic effects, Sedation, ECG (QT)
major_contraindications: Recent MI,Concurrent MAOIs,QT prolongation,Severe heart block,Urinary retention
black_box_warning_text: Suicidal ideation risk (especially young adults). Dangerous in overdose (cardiac toxicity).
major_drug_interactions: MAOIs (serotonin syndrome - fatal),QT-prolonging drugs,Anticholinergics (enhanced effects),SSRIs (increased TCA levels),Warfarin (increased INR)
food_interactions: Take at bedtime (sedating), avoid alcohol
notes: Low-dose TCA for neuropathic pain and migraine prevention (10-75mg). Full antidepressant dose 150mg+. Anticholinergic side effects. Sedating. NAFDAC-controlled due to abuse.

major_contraindications: Recent MI,Concurrent MAOIs,QT prolongation,Urinary retention
black_box_warning_text: Suicidal ideation risk. Cardiac toxicity in overdose.
major_drug_interactions: MAOIs (serotonin syndrome),QT-prolonging drugs,Anticholinergics,SSRIs (increased nortriptyline levels)
food_interactions: Take at bedtime or divided doses
notes: Active metabolite of amitriptyline. Better tolerated than amitriptyline (fewer anticholinergic effects). For neuropathic pain and migraine.

major_contraindications: Severe renal impairment,Severe hepatic impairment,Concurrent P-glycoprotein or strong CYP3A4 inhibitors in renal/hepatic impairment
major_drug_interactions: Clarithromycin (fatal colchicine toxicity),CYP3A4 inhibitors (increased toxicity),P-glycoprotein inhibitors (increased toxicity),Statins (myopathy risk)
food_interactions: Take with or without food, reduce dose in renal impairment
notes: For acute gout attacks and prevention. Narrow therapeutic window. Diarrhea common. Fatal toxicity possible with drug interactions. Dose adjust for renal/hepatic impairment.
